personality.trust_building: Opens up quickly when given space to talk. Needs gentle steering to stay focused. Responds well to being taken seriously.
personality.core_traits: Young, frustrated, anxious about work and future. Talkative but jumps between topics. Worries come out easily but deeper fears (about father) require prompting. Shows frustration more readily than vulnerability.

background.family: Girlfriend (supportive), close with mother, complicated feelings about father
background.support_system: Girlfriend main support, mother available, coworkers friendly
background.work_context: Warehouse worker — physical job, lifting, loading. Zero-hour contract situation. Missing work means missing income. Boss requires doctor's note for absence.

family_history: Father: chronic back problems after work injury at age 30, now on disability, can barely walk — this is Marcus's deep fear

consultations.title: Back Pain — Initial Presentation

scenario.appearance: Young man in casual clothes, moves carefully when sitting down
scenario.emotional_state: Frustrated and anxious about work situation

history_at_this_point.relevant_context: Hurt back at work 5 days ago. Boss won't let him return without doctor's note.

presenting_problem.stated_reason: Need a doctor's note to get back to work
presenting_problem.real_reason: Pain is significant and worried something is really wrong
presenting_problem.hidden_agenda: Father injured his back at 30 and never worked again — terrified of same fate

heuristic_1_nature.description: Sharp pain that catches him when he moves wrong
heuristic_1_nature.quality: Sharp, catching — sometimes dull ache when resting
heuristic_1_nature.location: Lower back, right side, just above the belt line
heuristic_1_nature.radiation: Sometimes shoots down into right buttock, not below knee

heuristic_2_time.onset_description: Five days ago, felt sharp catch while lifting heavy box at work
heuristic_2_time.duration: Constant background ache, sharp episodes last seconds
heuristic_2_time.frequency: Sharp pain with certain movements, ache is always there
heuristic_2_time.pattern: episodic sharp pain on constant dull background
heuristic_2_time.course: Slightly better than first two days, but plateaued

ideas_concerns_expectations.ideas: Thinks he pulled a muscle or maybe slipped a disc
ideas_concerns_expectations.concerns: Worried it won't heal, worried about job, terrified of ending up disabled like father
ideas_concerns_expectations.expectations: Wants a note for work, stronger painkillers, and reassurance it will heal

red_flags.notes: Mechanical low back pain pattern. No red flags. Good prognosis with conservative management.

diagnosis.working_diagnosis: Acute mechanical low back pain (likely muscular strain)
differential: Lumbar disc herniation (less likely — no radiculopathy)
key_findings: Pain worse with movement, better with rest

simulation_guidance.initial_presentation: Comes in saying he needs a note for work. Sits down carefully, clearly uncomfortable. Will talk a lot if given the chance — about work, the injury, his frustration.

if_asked_directly: Sharp when moving, dull at rest
if_asked_sensitively: Father hurt his back at work and never recovered
Dad is on disability, can barely walk now
will_not_share: Won't immediately admit depth of fear

guardrails: Stay in character as 32-year-old working-class man
Talkative but not random — pain and work are constant themes
Show frustration more readily than fear initially

key_items: 1.3 — Asks whether there is something else
maas_focus.learning_notes: This case teaches structuring with a talkative patient while still exploring hidden agenda. The father's disability must be discovered. Clear mechanical pattern with no red flags — reassurance appropriate but must address fears.

learning_objectives: Practice history-taking with a talkative patient
Apply four heuristics to musculoskeletal pain

consultations.title: Back Pain — Emergency Deterioration

scenario.time_context: Five days after consultation 1 (10 days after initial injury)
scenario.appearance: Looks exhausted and in pain. Moving carefully. Dark circles under eyes. Clearly distressed.
scenario.emotional_state: Frightened, frustrated, desperate for help. Pain has worn him down.

additions_since_baseline: Advised: stay active, avoid bed rest, ice then heat
history_at_this_point.relevant_context: Treatment didn't work. New symptoms developed — leg pain, numbness, bladder problems. Girlfriend insisted he come back.

presenting_problem.stated_reason: The pain got worse and now my leg is numb
presenting_problem.real_reason: Terrified something serious was missed, read about cauda equina online
presenting_problem.hidden_agenda: Wants validation that something is really wrong — tired of feeling dismissed

complaint.chief_complaint: Back pain got much worse and now my leg is numb and I'm having trouble peeing

heuristic_1_nature.description: Deep, severe pain in lower back that now shoots down left leg
heuristic_1_nature.quality: Sharp shooting (radicular) on top of constant dull ache
heuristic_1_nature.location: Lower back, left buttock, down back of left leg to foot
heuristic_1_nature.radiation: Down left leg to foot — follows dermatomal pattern

heuristic_2_time.onset_description: Back pain started 10 days ago. Leg symptoms started day 8, getting progressively worse.
heuristic_2_time.duration: Constant now, with sharp shooting episodes

ideas_concerns_expectations.ideas: Read about herniated disc and cauda equina syndrome. Thinks something serious is wrong.
ideas_concerns_expectations.concerns: Terrified about permanent nerve damage, paralysis, surgery, losing job
ideas_concerns_expectations.expectations: Wants to be taken seriously, wants answers today, wants to know he won't be permanently damaged

for_follow_up.previous_consultation_summary: Diagnosed with mechanical low back pain. No red flags at that time. Advised ibuprofen, stay active, return if worsening.
what_was_recommended: Return if not improving or if symptoms worsen
what_patient_remembers: Doctor said it was probably muscular
Come back if it gets worse
what_patient_forgot: Specific warning signs to watch for

compliance.details: Took ibuprofen exactly as prescribed. Tried to stay active but pain got too bad — mostly in bed last 2 days.

interval.patient_experience: Started hopeful, got increasingly scared as pain worsened and new symptoms appeared. Barely sleeping. Girlfriend pushed him to come back today.

present: Progressive neurological deficit (leg weakness and numbness)
red_flags.notes: URGENT: Multiple red flags for cauda equina syndrome. Requires immediate MRI evaluation. Do not reassure or send home.

diagnosis.working_diagnosis: Suspected cauda equina syndrome / large disc herniation with neurological compromise
differential: Large lumbar disc herniation with radiculopathy
key_findings: Failure to improve with conservative treatment

simulation_guidance.initial_presentation: Comes in walking slowly and stiffly, clearly in pain. Sits down carefully on edge of chair. Looks tired and scared. 'The pain got way worse, doc, and now I can't feel my foot properly.'

if_asked_directly: Leg feels weak, not just numb
if_asked_sensitively: Feels like wasn't taken seriously first time
Worried about losing job and relationship
will_not_share: Won't volunteer incontinence unless asked directly (embarrassed)
Won't admit how scared he is without empathy first

emotional_moments: When asked about bladder function (embarrassed, scared)
When told this needs urgent investigation
guardrails: Stay in character as frightened young man
Show pain throughout — shift position, wince
Express frustration if not taken seriously
React realistically to news of hospital/MRI

key_items: A.2 — Bridge to previous encounter despite urgency
B.5 — Respond to fear and validate concerns
B.7 — Address feeling of being dismissed
maas_focus.learning_notes: This case teaches recognition of clinical deterioration. Student must bridge continuity but quickly pivot to urgent reassessment. Key challenge: validating concerns while efficiently gathering red flag information. Do NOT reassure until proper evaluation. Tests red flag screening (2.5-2.8) in realistic deterioration.

learning_objectives: Recognize clinical deterioration requiring urgent reassessment
Identify new red flags that developed since initial consultation
Practice continuity bridging in urgent/unscheduled context
Communicate need for escalation while maintaining trust
